DIV1.HEAD: CALAIS.
DIV1.P: WHEN I had finish'd my dinâˆ£ner, and drank the King of France's health, to satisfy my mind that I bore him no spleen, but, on the contrary, high honour for the humaâˆ£nity of his temperâ€”I rose up an inch taller for the accommodation.

â€”Noâ€”said Iâ€”the Bourbon is by no means a cruel race: they may be misled like other people; but there is a mildness in their blood. As I acâˆ£knowledged this, I felt a suffusion of a finer kind upon my cheekâ€”more warm and friendly to man, than
what Burgundy (at least of two livres a bottle, which was such as I had been drinking) could have produced.

â€”Just God! said I, kicking my portmanteau aside, what is there in this world's goods which should sharpen our spirits, and make so many kind-hearted brethren of us, fall out so cruelly as we do by the way?

When man is at peace with man, how much lighter than a feather is the heaviest of metals in his hand! he pulls out his purse, and holding it airily and uncompress'd, looks round him, as if he sought for an object to share it withâ€”In doing this, I felt
every vessel in my frame dilateâ€”the arteries beat all chearily together, and every power which sustained life, perform'd it with so little friction, that 'twould have confounded the most physical precieuse in France: with all her materialism, she could scarce have called me a machineâ€”
I'm confident, said I to myself, I should have overset her creed.
The accession of that idea, carried nature, at that time, as high as she could goâ€”I was at peace with the world before, and this finish'd the treaty with myselfâ€”
â€”Now, was I a King of France, cried Iâ€”what a moment for an orâˆ£phan to have begg'd his father's portmanteau of me!

DIV1.HEAD: THE MONK.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P:
I HAD scarce utter'd the words, when a poor monk of the order of St. Francis came into the room to beg something for his convent. No man cares to have his virtues the sport of contingenciesâ€”or one man may be generous, as another man is puissantâ€”sed non, quo ad hancâ€”or be it as it mayâ€”for there is no regular reasoning upon the ebbs and flows of our humours; they may depend upon the same causes, for ought I know, which influence the tides themselvesâ€”'twould oft be no disâˆ£credit
to us, to suppose it was so: I'm sure at least for myself, that in many a case I should be more highly satisfied, to have it said by the world, "I had had an affair with the moon, in which there was neither sin nor shame," than have it pass altogether as my own act and deed, wherein there was so much of both.

â€”But be this as it may. The moment I cast my eyes upon him, I was predetermined not to give him a single sous; and accordingly I put my purse into my pocketâ€”button'd it upâ€”set myself a little more upon my centre, and advanced up gravely to him: there was something, I fear, forbidding in my look: I have his
figure this moment before my eyes, and think there was that in it which deserved better.

The monk, as I judged from the break in his tonsure, a few scatter'd white hairs upon his temples, being all that remained of it, might be about seventyâ€”but from his eyes, and that sort of fire which was in them, which seemed more temper'd by courtesy than years, could be no more than sixtyâ€”Truth might lie betweenâ€”He was certainly sixty-five; and the general air of his counteâˆ£nance, notwithstanding something seem'd to have been planting wrinkles in it before their time, agreed to the account.

It was one of those heads, which Guido has often paintedâ€”mild, paleâ€”penetrating, free from all comâˆ£mon-place ideas of fat contented igâˆ£norance looking downwards upon the earthâ€”it look'd forwards; but look'd, as if it look'd at something beyond this world. How one of his order came by it, heaven above, who let it fall upon a monk's shoulders, best knows: but it would have suited a Bramin, and had I met it upon the plains of Indostan, I had reverenced it.

The rest of his outline may be given in a few strokes; one might put it into the hands of any one to design, for 'twas neither elegant or
otherwise, but as character and exâˆ£pression made it so: it was a thin, spare form, something above the common size, if it lost not the disâˆ£tinction by a bend forwards in the figureâ€”but it was the attitude of Intreaty; and as it now stands preâˆ£sented to my imagination, it gain'd more than it lost by it.

When he had enter'd the room three paces, he stood still; and layâˆ£ing his left hand upon his breast, (a slender white staff with which he journey'd being in his right)â€”when I had got close up to him, he introâˆ£duced himself with the little story of the wants of his convent, and the poverty of his orderâ€”and did it with
so simple a graceâ€”and such an air of deprecation was there in the whole cast of his look and figureâ€”I was beâˆ£witch'd not to have been struck with itâ€”
â€”A better reason was, I had preâˆ£determined not to give him a single sous.

DIV1.HEAD: THE MONK.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: â€”'TIS very true, said I, replyâˆ£ing to a cast upwards with his eyes, with which he had conâˆ£cluded his addressâ€”'tis very trueâ€”and heaven be their resource who have no other but the charity of the world, the stock of which, I fear, is no way sufficient for the many great claims which are hourly made upon it.

As I pronounced the words great claims, he gave a slight glance with his eye downwards upon the sleeve
of his tunickâ€”I felt the full force of the appealâ€”I acknowledge it, said Iâ€”a coarse habit, and that but once in three years, with meagre dietâ€”are no great matters; and the true point of pity is, as they can be earn'd in the world with so little industry, that your order should wish to proâˆ£cure them by pressing upon a fund which is the property of the lame, the blind, the aged and the infirmâ€”the captive who lies down counting over and over again the days of his afâˆ£flictions, languishes also for his share of it; and had you been of the order of mercy, instead of the order of St. Francis, poor as I am, continued I, pointing at my portmanteau, full chearfully should it have been open'd
to you, for the ransom of the unforâˆ£tunateâ€”The monk made me a bowâ€”but of all others, resumed I, the unfortunate of our own country, surely, have the first rights; and I have left thousands in distress upon our own shoreâ€”The monk gave a cordial wave with his headâ€”as much as to say, No doubt, there is misery enough in every corner of the world, as well as within our conventâ€”But we distinguish, said I, laying my hand upon the sleeve of his tunick, in return for his appealâ€”we distinâˆ£guish, my good Father! betwixt those who wish only to eat the bread of their own labourâ€”and those who eat the bread of other people's, and have no other plan in life, but to get
through it in sloth and ignorance, for the love of God.

The poor Franciscan made no reâˆ£ply: a hectic of a moment pass'd across his cheek, but could not tarryâ€”Nature seemed to have had done with her resentments in him; he shewed noneâ€”but letting his staff fall within his arm, he press'd both his hands with resignation upon his breast, and retired.

DIV1.HEAD: THE MONK.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P:
MY heart smote me the moment he shut the doorâ€”Psha! said I with an air of carelessness, three several timesâ€”but it would not do: every ungracious syllable I had utâˆ£ter'd, crouded back into my imagiâˆ£nation: I reflected, I had no right over the poor Franciscan, but to deâˆ£ny him; and that the punishment of that was enough to the disappointed without the addition of unkind lanâˆ£guageâ€”I consider'd his grey hairsâ€”his courteous figure seem'd to reâˆ£enter and gently ask me what injury he had done me?â€”and why I could
use him thusâ€”I would have given twenty livres for an advocateâ€”I have behaved very ill; said I within myself; but I have only just set out upon my travels; and shall learn better manners as I get along.

DIV1.HEAD: THE DESOBLIGEANT.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P:
WHEN a man is discontented with himself, it has one adâˆ£vantage however, that it puts him into an excellent frame of mind for making a bargain. Now there being no travelling through France and Italy without a chaiseâ€”and nature generally prompting us to the thing we are fittest for, I walk'd out into the coach yard to buy or hire someâˆ£thing of that kind to my purpose: an old A chaise, so called in France, from its bolding but one person. Desobligeant in the furthest corner of the court, hit my fancy at first sight, so I instantly got into it,
and finding it in tolerable harmony with my feelings, I ordered the waiter to call Monsieur Dessein the master of the hÃ´telâ€”but Monsieur Dessein being gone to vespers, and not caring to face the Franciscan whom I saw on the opposite side of the court, in conference with a lady just arrived, at the innâ€”I drew the taffeta curtain betwixt us, and being determined to write my journey, I took out my pen and ink, and wrote the preface to it in the Disobligeant.

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE, IN THE DESOBLIGEANT.
DIV1.P:
IT must have been observed by many a peripatetic philosopher, That nature has set up by her own unquestionable authority certain boundaries and fences to circumâˆ£scribe the discontent of man: she has effected her purpose in the quietest and easiest manner by laying him under almost insuperable obligations to work out his ease, and to sustain his sufferings at home. It is there only that she has provided him with the most suitable objects to partake of his happiness, and bear a part of that burden which in all countries and ages, has ever been too heavy
for one pair of shoulders. 'Tis true we are endued with an imperfect power of spreading our happiness sometimes beyond her limits, but 'tis so ordered, that from the want of languages, connections, and deâˆ£pendencies, and from the difference in education, customs and habits, we lie under so many impediments in communicating our sensations out of our own sphere, as often amount to a total impossibility.

It will always follow from hence, that the balance of sentimental comâˆ£merce is always against the expaâˆ£triated adventurer: he must buy what he has little occasion for at their own priceâ€”his conversation
will seldom be taken in exchange for theirs without a large discountâ€”and this, by the by, eternally drivâˆ£ing him into the hands of more equitable brokers for such converâˆ£sation as he can find, it requires no great spirit of divination to guess at his partyâ€”
This brings me to my point; and naturally leads me (if the see-saw of this Desobligeant will but let me get on) into the efficient as well as the final causes of travellingâ€”

Your idle people that leave their native country and go abroad for some reason or reasons which may be derived from one of these general causesâ€”
Infirmity of body,
Imbecility of mind, or
Inevitable necessity. The first two include all those who travel by land or by water, laâˆ£bouring with pride, curiosity, vanity or spleen, subdivided and combined in infinitum.

The third class includes the whole army of peregrine martyrs; more especially those travellers who set out upon their travels with the beâˆ£nefit of the clergy, either as delinâˆ£quents travelling under the direction of governors recommended by the magistrateâ€”or young gentlemen transported by the cruelty of paâˆ£rents and guardians, and travelling under the direction of governors reâˆ£commended
by Oxford, Aberdeen and Glasgow.

There is a fourth class, but their number is so small that they would not deserve a distinction, was it not necessary in a work of this nature to observe the greatest precision and nicety, to avoid a confusion of chaâˆ£racter. And these men I speak of, are such as cross the seas and sojourn in a land of strangers with a view of saving money for various reasons and upon various pretences: but as they might also save themselves and others a great deal of unnecessary trouble by saving their money at homeâ€”and as their reasons for travelling are the least complex of any other species of emigrants, I shall diâˆ£stinguish
these gentlemen by the name of
Simple Travellers.

Thus the whole circle of travellers may be reduced to the following Heads.
Idle Travellers,
Inquisitive Travellers,
Lying Travellers,
Proud Travellers,
Vain Travellers,
Splenetic Travellers.

Then follow the Travellers of Necessity.
The delinquent and felonious Traveller,
The unfortunate and innocent Traveller,
The simple Traveller,
And last of all (if you please)
The Sentimental Traveller
(meaning thereby myself) who have travell'd, and of which I am now sitting down to give an accountâ€”as much out of Necessity, and the besoin de Voyager, as any one in the class.

I am well aware, at the same time, as both my travels and observations will be altogether of a different cast from any of my fore-runners; that I might have insisted upon a whole nitch entirely to myselfâ€”but I should break in upon the confines of the Vain Traveller, in wishing to draw attention towards me, till I have some better grounds for it, than the mere Novelty of my Veâˆ£hicle.

It is sufficient for my reader, if he has been a traveller himself, that with study and reflection hereupon he may be able to determine his own place and rank in the cataâˆ£logueâ€”it will be one step towards knowing himself; as it is great odds, but he retains some tincture and resemblance, of what he imbibed or carried out, to the present hour.

The man who first transplanted the grape of Burgundy to the Cape of Good Hope (observe he was a Dutch man) never dreamt of drinkâˆ£ing the same wine at the Cape, that the same grape produced upon the French mountainsâ€”he was too phlegmatic for thatâ€”but undoubtâˆ£edly
he expected to drink some sort of vinous liquor; but whether good, bad, or indifferentâ€”he knew enough of this world to know, that it did not depend upon his choice, but that what is generally called chance was to decide his success: however, he hoped for the best; and in these hopes, by an intemperate confidence in the fortitude of his head, and the depth of his discretion, Mynheer might possibly overset both in his new vineyard; and by discovering his nakedness, become a laughingâˆ£stock to his people.

Even so it fares with the poor Traveller, sailing and posting through the politer kingdoms of the globe
in pursuit of knowledge and imâˆ£provements.

Knowledge and improvements are to be got by sailing and posting for that purpose; but whether useâˆ£ful knowledge and real improveâˆ£ments, is all a lotteryâ€”and even where the adventurer is successful, the acquired stock must be used with caution and sobriety to turn to any profitâ€”but as the chances run prodigiously the other way both as to the acquisition and application, I am of opinion, That a man would act as wisely, if he could prevail upon himself, to live conâˆ£tented without foreign knowledge or foreign improvements, especially
if he lives in a country that has no absolute want of eitherâ€”and indeed, much grief of heart has it oft and many a time cost me, when I have observed how many a foul step the inquisitive Traveller has measured to see sights and look into discoâˆ£veries; all which, as Sancho Panca said to Don Quixote, they might have seen dry-shod at home. It is an age so full of light, that there is scarce a country or corner of Euâˆ£rope whose beams are not crossed and interchanged with othersâ€”Knowledge in most of its branches, and in most affairs, is like music in an Italian street, whereof those may partake, who pay nothingâ€”But there is no nation under heaven
â€”and God is my record, (before whose tribunal I must one day come and give an account of this work)â€”that I do not speak it vauntinglyâ€”But there is no nation under heaven abounding with more variety of learnâˆ£ingâ€”where the sciences may be more fitly woo'd, or more surely won than hereâ€”where art is encouraged, and will so soon rise highâ€”where Nature (take her all together) has so little to answer forâ€”and, to close all, where there is more wit and variety of chaâˆ£racter to feed the mind withâ€”Where then, my dear countrymen, are you goingâ€”

â€”We are only looking at this chaise, said theyâ€”Your most obeâˆ£dient
servant, said I, skipping out of it, and pulling off my hatâ€”We were wondering, said one of them, who, I found, was an inquisitive travellerâ€”what could occasion its motion.â€”â€”'Twas the agitation, said I coolly, of writing a prefaceâ€”I never heard, said the other, who was a simple traâˆ£veller, of a preface wrote in a Desoâˆ£bligeant.â€”It would have been better, said I, in a Vis a Vis.
â€”As an English man does not travel to see English men, I retired to my room.

DIV1.HEAD: CALAIS.
DIV1.P:
I Perceived that something darken'd the passage more than myself, as I stepp'd along it to my room; it was effectually Mons. Dessein, the master of the hÃ´tel, who had just reâˆ£turn'd from vespers, and, with his hat under his arm, was most comâˆ£plaisantly following me, to put me in mind of my wants. I had wrote myâˆ£self pretty well out of conceit with the Desobligeant; and Mons. Dessein speaking of it, with a shrug, as if it would no way suit me, it immediately struck my fancy that it belong'd to some innocent traveller, who, on his
return home, had left it to Mons. Dessein's honour to make the most of. Four months had elapsed since it had finish'd its career of Europe in the corner of Mons. Dessein's coachâˆ£yard; and having sallied out from thence but a vampt-up business at the first, though it had been twice taken to pieces on Mount Sennis, it had not profited much by its advenâˆ£turesâ€”but by none so little as the standing so many months unpitied in the corner of Mons. Dessein's coachâˆ£yard. Much indeed was not to be said for itâ€”but something mightâ€”and when a few words will rescue misery out of her distress, I hate the man who can be a churl of them.

â€”Now was I the master of this hÃ´tel, said I, laying the point of my fore-finger on Mons. Dessein's breast, I would inevitably make a point of getting rid of this unfortunate Desoâˆ£bligeantâ€”itstands swinging reproaches at you every time you pass by itâ€”

Mon Dieu! said Mons. Desseinâ€”I have no interestâ€”Except the inâˆ£terest, said I, which men of a certain turn of mind take, Mons. Dessein, in their own sensationsâ€”I'm persuaded, to a man who feels for others as well as for himself, every rainy night, disâˆ£guise it as you will, must cast a damp upon your spiritsâ€”You suffer, Mons. Dessein, as much as the machineâ€”

I have always observed, when there is as much sour as sweet in a compliâˆ£ment, that an Englishman is eternally at a loss within himself, whether to take it, or let it alone: a Frenchman never is: Mons. Dessein made me a bow.

C'est bien vrai, said heâ€”But in this case I should only exchange one disâˆ£quietude for another, and with loss: figure to yourself, my dear Sir, that in giving you a chaise which would fall to pieces before you had got half way to Parisâ€”figure to yourself how much I should suffer, in giving an ill impression of myself to a man of hoâˆ£nour, and lying at the mercy, as I must do, d'un homme d'esprit.

The dose was made up exactly after my own prescription; so I could not help taking itâ€”and returning Mons. Dessein his bow, without more casuistry we walk'd together towards his Remise, to take a view of his magazine of chaises.

DIV1.HEAD: IN THE STREET.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P:
IT must needs be a hostile kind of a world, when the buyer (if it be but of a sorry post-chaise) canâˆ£not go forth with the seller thereâˆ£of into the street to terminate the difference betwixt them, but he inâˆ£stantly falls into the same frame of mind and views his conventionist with the same sort of eye, as if he was going along with him to Hydeâˆ£park corner to fight a duel. For my own part, being but a poor sword'sâˆ£man, and no way a match for Monâˆ£sieur Dessein, I felt the rotation of
all the movements within me, to which the situation is incidentâ€”I looked at Monsieur Dessein through and throughâ€”ey'd him as he walked along in profileâ€”then, en faceâ€”thought he look'd like a Jewâ€”then a Turkâ€”disliked his wigâ€”cursed him by my godsâ€”wished him at the devilâ€”

â€”And is all this to be lighted up in the heart for a beggarly acâˆ£count of three or four louisd'ors, which is the most I can be overâˆ£reach'd in?â€”Base passion! said I, turning myself about, as a man naâˆ£turally does upon a sudden reverse of sentimentâ€”base, ungentle passion! thy hand is against every man, and
every man's hand against theeâ€”heaven forbid! said she, raising her hand up to her forehead, for I had turned full in front upon the lady whom I had seen in conference with the monkâ€”she had followed us unperceivedâ€”Heaven forbid indeed! said I, offering her my ownâ€”she had a black pair of silk gloves open only at the thumb and two foreâˆ£fingers, so accepted it without reâˆ£serveâ€”and I led her up to the door of the Remise.

Monsieur Dessein had diabled the key above fifty times before he found out he had come with a wrong one in his hand: we were as impatient as himself to have it open'd; and so
attentive to the obstacle, that I conâˆ£tinued holding her hand almost withâˆ£out knowing it; so that Monsieur Dessein left us together with her hand in mine, and with our faces turned towards the door of the Remise, and said he would be back in five minutes.

Now a colloquy of five miâˆ£nutes, in such a situation, is worth one of as many ages, with your faces turned towards the street: in the latter case, 'tis drawn from the objects and occurrences withâˆ£outâ€”when your eyes are fixed upon a dead blankâ€”you draw purely from yourselves. A silence of a single moment upon Monsieur Dessein's
leaving us, had been fatal: to the situationâ€”she had infallibly turned aboutâ€”so I begun the conversation instantly.â€”

â€”But what were the temptations, (as I write not to apologize for the weaknesses of my heart in this tour,â€”but to give an account of them)â€”shall be described with the same simplicity, with which I felt them.

DIV1.HEAD: THE REMISE DOOR.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: WHEN I told the reader that I did not care to get out of the Desobligeant, because I saw the monk in close conference with a lady just arrived at the innâ€”I told him the truth; but I did not tell him the whole truth; for I was full as much restrained by the appearance and figure of the lady he was talking to. Suspicion crossed my brain, and said, he was telling her what had passed: something jarred upon it within meâ€”I wished him at his convent.

When the heart flies out before the understanding, it saves the judgâˆ£ment a world of painsâ€”I was cerâˆ£tain she was of a better order of beingsâ€”however, I thought no more of her, but went on and wrote my preface.

The impression returned, upon my encounter with her in the street; a guarded frankness with which she gave me her hand, shewed, I thought, her good education and her good sense; and as I led her on, I felt a pleasurable ductility about her, which spread a calmness over all my spiritsâ€”
â€”Good God! how a man might lead such a creature as this round the world with him!â€”

I had not yet seen her faceâ€”'twas not material; for the drawing was instantly set about, and long before we had got to the door of the Remise, Fancy had finished the whole head, and pleased herself as much with its fitting her goddess, as if she had dived into the TIBER for itâ€”but thou art a seduced, and a seâˆ£ducing slut; and albeit thou cheatest us seven times a day with thy picâˆ£tures and images, yet with so many charms dost thou do it, and thou deckest out thy pictures in the shapes of so many angels of light, 'tis a shame to break with thee.

When we had got to the door of the Remise, she withdrew her hand from across her forehead, and let me see the originalâ€”it was a face of about six and twentyâ€”of a clear transparent brown, simply set off without rouge or powderâ€”it was not critically handsome, but there was that in it, which in the frame of mind I was in, which attached me much more to itâ€”it was interesting; I fancied it wore the characters of a widow'd look, and in that state of its declension, which had passed the two first paroxysms of sorrow, and was quietly beginning to reconcile itself to its lossâ€”but a thousand other distresses might have traced the same lines; I wish'd to know
what they had beenâ€”and was ready to enquire, (had the same bon ton of conversation permitted, as in the days of Esdras)â€”"What aileth thee? and why art thou disquieted? and why is thy understanding troubled?"â€”In a word, I felt benevolence for her; and resolved some way or other to throw in my mite of courtesyâ€”if not of service.

Such were my temptationsâ€”and in this disposition to give way to them, was I left alone with the lady with her hand in mine, and with our faces both turned closer to the door of the Remise than what was abâˆ£solutely necessary.

DIV1.HEAD: THE REMISE DOOR.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: THIS certainly, fair lady! said I, raising her hand up a little lightly as I began, must be one of Fortune's whimsical doings: to take two utter strangers by their handsâ€”of different sexes, and perâˆ£haps from different corners of the globe, and in one moment place them together in such a cordial situâˆ£ation, as Friendship herself could scarce have atchieved for them, had she projected it for a monthâ€”
â€”And your reflection upon it, shews how much, Monsieur, she has embarassed you by the adventure.â€”

When the situation is, what we would wish, nothing is so ill-timed as to hint at the circumstances which make it so: you thank Fortune, conâˆ£tinued sheâ€”you had reasonâ€”the heart knew it, and was satisfied; and who but an English philosopher would have sent notices of it to the brain to reverse the judgment?
In saying this, she disengaged her hand with a look which I thought a sufficient commentary upon the text.

It is a miserable picture which I am going to give of the weakness of my heart, by owning, that it suffered a pain, which worthier occasions could not have inflicted.â€”I was mortified with the loss of her hand, and the manner in which I had lost it carried neither oil nor wine to the wound: I never felt the pain of a sheepish inferiority so miserably in my life.

The triumphs of a true feminine heart are short upon these discomfiâˆ£tures. In a very few seconds she laid her hand upon the cuff of my coat, in order to finish her reply; so some way or other, God knows how, I regained my situation.
â€”She had nothing to add.

I forthwith began to model a difâˆ£ferent conversation for the lady, thinking from the spirit as well as moral of this, that I had been miâˆ£staken in her character; but upon turning her face towards me, the spirit which had animated the reply was fledâ€”the muscles relaxed, and I beheld the same unprotected look of distress which first won me to her interestâ€”melancholy! to see such sprightliness the prey of sorrow.â€”I pitied her from my soul; and though it may seem ridiculous enough to a torpid heart,â€”I could have taken her into my arms, and cherished her,
though it was in the open street, without blushing.
The pulsations of the arteries along my fingers pressing across hers, told her what was passing within me: she looked downâ€”a silence of some moâˆ£ments followed.

I fear, in this interval, I must have made some slight efforts toâˆ£wards a closer compression of her hand, from a subtle sensation I felt in the palm of my ownâ€”not as if she was going to withdraw hersâ€”but, as if she thought about itâ€”and I had infallibly lost it a second time, had not instinct more than reaâˆ£son directed me to the last resource
in these dangersâ€”to hold it loosely, and in a manner as if I was every moment going to release it, of myâˆ£self; so she let it continue, till Monâˆ£sieur Dessein returned with the key; and in the mean time I set myself to consider how I should undo the ill impressions which the poor monk's story, in case he had told it her, must have planted in her breast against me.

DIV1.HEAD: THE SNUFF-BOX.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P:
THE good old monk was within six paces of us, as the idea of him cross'd my mind; and was adâˆ£vancing towards us a little out of the line, as if uncertain whether he should break in upon us or no.â€”He stopp'd, however, as soon as he came up to us, with a world of frankness; and having a horn snuff-box in his hand, he presented it open to meâ€”You shall taste mineâ€”said I, pulling out my box (which was a small tortoise one) and putting it into his handâ€”
'Tis most excellent, said the monk; Then do me the favour, I replied, to accept of the box and all, and when you take a pinch out of it, sometimes recollect it was the peace-offering of a man who once used you unkindly, but not from his heart.

The poor monk blush'd as red as scarlet. Mon Dieu! said he, pressâˆ£ing his hands togetherâ€”you never used me unkindly.â€”I should think, said the lady, he is not likely. I blush'd in my turn; but from what movements, I leave to the few who feel to analyseâ€”Excuse me, Madame, replied Iâ€”I treated him most unâˆ£kindly; and from no provocationsâ€”'Tis impossible, said the lady.â€”My
God! cried the monk, with a warmth of asseveration which seemed not to belong to himâ€”the fault was in me, and in the indiscretion of my zealâ€”the lady opposed it, and I joined with her in maintaining it was impossible, that a spirit so regulated as his, could give offence to any.

I knew not that contention could be rendered so sweet and pleasurable a thing to the nerves as I then felt it.â€”We remained silent, without any sensation of that foolish pain which takes place, when in such a circle you look for ten minutes in one another's faces without saying a word. Whilst this lasted, the monk rubb'd his horn box upon the sleeve of his tunick;
and as soon as it had acquired a little air of brightness by the frictionâ€”he made a low bow, and said, 'twas too late to say whether it was the weakâˆ£ness or goodness of our tempers which had involved us in this contestâ€”but be it as it wouldâ€”he begg'd we might exchange boxesâ€”In sayâˆ£ing this, he presented his to me with one hand, as he took mine from me in the other; and having kiss'd itâ€”with a stream of good nature in his eyes he put it into his bosomâ€”and took his leave.

I guard this box, as I would the instrumental parts of my religion, to help my mind on to something betâˆ£ter: in truth, I seldom go abroad
without it; and oft and many a time have I called up by it the courteous spirit of its owner to regulate my own, in the justlings of the world; they had found full employment for his, as I learnt from his story, till about the forty-fifth year of his age, when upon some military services ill reâˆ£quited, and meeting at the same time with a disappointment in the tenâˆ£derest of passions, he abandon'd the sword and the sex together, and took sanctuary, not so much in his conâˆ£vent as in himself.

I feel a damp upon my spirits, as I am going to add, that in my last return through Calais, upon inquirâˆ£ing after Father Lorenzo, I heard
he had been dead near three months, and was buried, not in his convent, but, according to his desire, in a little cimetiery belonging to it, about two leagues off: I had a strong desire to see where they had laid himâ€”when, upon pulling out his little horn box, as I sat by his grave, and plucking up a nettle or two at the head of it, which had no business to grow there, they all struck together so forcibly upon my affections, that I burst into a flood of tearsâ€”but I am as weak as a woman; and I beg the world not to smile, but pity me.

DIV1.HEAD: THE REMISE DOOR.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: I HAD never quitted the lady's hand all this time; and had held it so long, that it would have been indecent to have let it go, without first pressing it to my lips: the blood and spirits, which had suffer'd a reâˆ£vulsion from her, crouded back to her, as I did it.

Now the two travellers who had spoke to me in the coach-yard, hapâˆ£pening at that crisis to be passing by, and observing our communications, naturally took it into their heads that
we must be man and wife at least; so stopping as soon as they came up to the door of the Remise, the one of them, who was the inquisitive traâˆ£veller, ask'd us, if we set out for Paris the next morning?â€”I could only answer for myself, I said; and the lady added, she was for Amiens.â€”We dined there yesterday, said the simple travellerâ€”You go directly through the town, added the other, in your road to Paris. I was going to return a thousand thanks for the intelligence, that Amiens was in the road to Paris; but, upon pulling out my poor monk's little horn box to take a pinch of snuffâ€”I made them a quiet bow, and wishing them a
good passage to Doverâ€”they left us aloneâ€”
â€”Now where would be the harm, said I to myself, if I was to beg of this distressed lady to accept of half of my chaise?â€”and what mighty mischief could ensue?

Every dirty passion, and bad proâˆ£pensity in my nature, took the alarm, as I stated the propositionâ€”It will oblige you to have a third horse, said AVARICE, which will put twenty livres out of your pocket.â€”You know not who she is, said CAUTIONâ€”or what scrapes the affair may draw you into, whisper'd COWARDICEâ€”
Depend upon it, Yorick! said DISCRETION, 'twill be said you went off with a mistress, and came by asâˆ£signation to Calais for that purposeâ€”
â€”You can never after, cried HYâˆ£POCRISY aloud, shew your face in the worldâ€”or rise, quoth MEANNESS, in the churchâ€”or be any thing in it, said PRIDE, but a lousy prebendary.

â€”But 'tis a civil thing, said Iâ€”and as I generally act from the first impulse, and therefore seldom listen to these cabals, which serve no purâˆ£pose, that I know of, but to encomâˆ£pass the heart with adamantâ€”I turn'd instantly about to the ladyâ€”

â€”But she had glided off unperâˆ£ceived, as the cause was pleading, and had made ten or a dozen paces down the street, by the time I had made the determination; so I set off after her with a long stride, to make her the proposal with the best address I was master of; but observâˆ£ing she walk'd with her cheek half resting upon the palm of her handâ€”with the slow, short-measur'd step of thoughtfulness, and with her eyes, as she went step by step, fix'd upon the ground, it struck me, she was trying the same cause herself.â€”God help her! said I, she has some mother-in-law, or tartufish aunt, or nonsensical old woman, to consult upon the ocâˆ£casion, as well as myself: so not carâˆ£ing
to interrupt the processe, and deeming it more gallant to take her at discretion than by surprize, I faced about, and took a short turn or two before the door of the Remise, whilst she walk'd musing on one side.

DIV1.HEAD: IN THE STREET.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: HAVING, on first sight of the lady, settled the affair in my fancy, "that she was of the better order of beings"â€”and then laid it down as a second axiom, as indisputâˆ£able as the first, That she was a wiâˆ£dow, and wore a character of disâˆ£tressâ€”I went no further; I got ground enough for the situation which pleased meâ€”and had she remained close beâˆ£side my elbow till midnight, I should have held true to my system, and considered her only under that geneâˆ£ral idea.

She had scarce got twenty paces distant from me, ere something within me called out for a more particular inquiryâ€”it brought on the idea of a further separationâ€”I might possibly never see her moreâ€”the heart is for saving what it can; and I wanted the traces thro' which my wishes might find their way to her, in case I should never rejoin her myself: in a word, I wish'd to know her nameâ€”her faâˆ£mily'sâ€”her condition; and as I knew the place to which she was going, I wanted to know from whence she came: but there was no coming at all this intelligence: a hundred little delicacies stood in the way. I form'd a score different plansâ€”There was
no such thing as a man's asking her directlyâ€”the thing was impossible.

A little French debonaire captain, who came dancing down the street, shewed me, it was the easiest thing in the world; for popping in betwixt us, just as the lady was returning back to the door of the Remise, he introâˆ£duced himself to my acquaintance, and before he had well got announâˆ£ced, begg'd I would do him the hoâˆ£nour to present him to the ladyâ€”I had not been presented myselfâ€”so turning about to her, he did it just as well by asking her, if she had come from Paris?â€”No: she was going that rout, she said.â€”Vous n'etez pas de Londre?â€”She was not, she replied.

â€”Then Madame must have come thro' Flanders.â€”Apparamment vous etez Flammande? said the French capâˆ£tain.â€”The lady answered, she was.â€”Peutetre, de Lisle? added heâ€”She said, she was not of Lisle.â€”Nor Arâˆ£ras?â€”nor Cambray?â€”nor Ghent?â€”nor Brussels? She answered, she was of Brussels.

He had had the honour, he said, to be at the bombardment of it last warâ€”that it was finely situated, pour celaâ€”and full of noblesse when the Imperialists were driven out by the French (the lady made a slight curtsy)â€”so giving her an account of the afâˆ£fair, and of the share he had had in
itâ€”he begg'd the honour to know her nameâ€”so made his bow.
â€”Et Madame a son Mari?â€”said he, looking back when he had made two stepsâ€”and without staying for an answerâ€”danced down the street.
Had I served seven years apprenâˆ£ticeship to good breeding, I could not have done as much.

DIV1.HEAD: THE REMISE.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: AS the little French captain left us, Mons. Dessein came up with the key of the Remise in his hand, and forthwith let us into his magazine of chaises.

The first object which caught my eye, as Mons. Dessein open'd the door of the Remise, was another old tatter'd Desobligeant: and notwithâˆ£standing it was the exact picture of that which had hit my fancy so much in the coach-yard but an hour beforeâ€”the very sight of it stirr'd up a
disagreeable sensation within me now; and I thought 'twas a churlish beast into whose heart the idea could first enter, to construct such a machine; nor had I much more charity for the man who could think of using it.

I observed the lady was as little taken with it as myself: so Mons. Dessein led us on to a couple of chaises which stood abreast, telling us as he recommended them, that they had been purchased by my Lord A. and B. to go the grand tour, but had gone no further than Paris, so were in all respects as good as newâ€”They were too goodâ€”so I pass'd on to a third, which stood behind, and forthwith began to chaffer for the
priceâ€”But 'twill scarce hold two, said I, opening the door and getting inâ€”Have the goodness, Madam, said Mons. Dessein, offering his arm, to step inâ€”The lady hesitated half a seâˆ£cond, and stepp'd in; and the waiter that moment beckoning to speak to Mons. Dessein, he shut the door of the chaise upon us, and left us.

DIV1.HEAD: THE REMISE.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: C'EST bien comique, 'tis very droll, said the lady smiling, from the reflection that this was the seâˆ£cond time we had been left toâˆ£gether by a parcel of nonsensical contingenciesâ€”c'est bien comique, said sheâ€”
â€”There wants nothing, said I, to make it so, but the comick use which the gallantry of a Frenchâˆ£man would put it toâ€”to make love the first moment, and an offer of his person the second.
'Tis their fort: replied the lady.

It is supposed so at leastâ€”and how it has come to pass, continued I, I know not; but they have certainly got the credit of understanding more of love, and making it better than any other nation upon earth: but for my own part I think them errant bunglers, and in truth the worst set of marksmen that ever tried Cupid's patience.
â€”To think of making love by sentiments!

I should as soon think of making a genteel suit of cloaths out of remâˆ£nants:â€”and to do itâ€”popâ€”at first sight by declarationâ€”is submitting
the offer and themselves with it, to be sifted, with all their pours and contres, by an unheated mind.
The lady attended as if she exâˆ£pected I should go on.
Consider then, madam, continued I, laying my hand upon hersâ€”
That grave people hate Love for the name's sakeâ€”
That selfish people hate it for their ownâ€”
Hypocrites for heaven'sâ€”

And that all of us both old and young, being ten times worse
frighten'd than hurt by the very reportâ€”What a want of knowledge in this branch of commerce a man betrays, whoever lets the word come out of his lips, till an hour or two at least after the time, that his silence upon it becomes tormenting. A course of small, quiet attentions, not so pointed as to alarmâ€”nor so vague as to be misunderstood,â€”with now and then a look of kindness, and little or nothing said upon itâ€”leaves Nature for your mistress, and she fashions it to her mind.â€”
Then I solemnly declare, said the lady, blushingâ€”you have been makâˆ£ing love to me all this while.

DIV1.HEAD: THE REMISE.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: MONSIEUR Dessein came back to let us out of the chaise, and acquaint the lady, the Count de L her brother was just arrived at the hotel. Though I had infinite good will for the lady, I cannot say, that I rejoiced in my heart at the eventâ€”and could not help telling her soâ€”for it is fatal to a proposal, Madam, said I, that I was going to make youâ€”

â€”You need not tell me what the proposal was, said she, laying her
hand upon both mine, as she interâˆ£rupted me.â€”A man, my good Sir, has seldom an offer of kindness to make-to a woman, but she has a presentiment of it some moments beforeâ€”

Nature arms her with it, said I, for immediate preservationâ€”But I think, said she, looking in my face, I had no evil to apprehendâ€”and to deal frankly with you, had deterâˆ£mined to accept it.â€”If I hadâ€”(she stopped a moment)â€”I believe your good will would have drawn a story from me, which would have made pity the only dangerous thing in the journey.
In saying this, she suffered me to kiss her hand twice, and with a look of sensibility mixed with a concern she got out of the chaiseâ€”and bid adieu.

DIV1.HEAD: IN THE STREET.
CALAIS.
DIV1.P: I NEVER finished a twelve-guinea bargain so expeditiously in my life: my time seemed heavy upon the loss of the lady, and knowing every moment of it would be as two, till I put myself into motionâ€”I ordered post horses directly, and walked towards the hotel.
Lord! said I, hearing the town clock strike four, and recollecting that I had been little more than a single hour in Calaisâ€”

â€”What a large volume of adâˆ£ventures may be grasped within this little span of life by him who inâˆ£terests his heart in every thing, and who, having eyes to see, what time and chance are perpetually holding out to him as he journeyeth on his way, misses nothing he can fairly lay his hands on.â€”

â€”If this won't turn out somethingâ€”another willâ€”no matterâ€”'tis an assay upon human natureâ€”I get my labour for my painsâ€”'tis enoughâ€”the pleasure of the experiment has kept my senses, and the best part of my blood awake, and laid the gross to sleep.

I pity the man who can travel from Dan to Beersheba, and cry, 'Tis all barrenâ€”and so it is; and so is all the world to him who will not cultiâˆ£vate the fruits it offers. I declare, said I, clapping my hands chearily together, that was I in a desart, I would find out wherewith in it to call forth my affectionsâ€”If I could not do better, I would fasten them upon some sweet myrtle, or seek some meâˆ£lancholy cypress to connect myself toâ€”I would court their shade, and greet them kindly for their protecâˆ£tionâ€”I would cut my name upon them, and swear they were the loveâˆ£liest trees throughout the desert: if their leaves wither'd, I would teach
myself to mourn, and when they reâˆ£joiced, I would rejoice along with them.

The learned SMELFUNGUS travelâˆ£led from Boulogne to Parisâ€”from Paris to Romeâ€”and so onâ€”but he set out with the spleen and jaundice, and every object he pafs'd by was discoloured or distortedâ€”He wrote an account of them, but'twas nothing but the account of his miserable feelâˆ£ings.

I met Smelfungus in the grand portico of the Pantheonâ€”he was just coming out of itâ€”'Tis nothing but a huge cock-pitVide S's Travels., said heâ€”I wish you had said nothing worse of the Venus
of Medicis, replied Iâ€”for in passing through Florence, I had heard he had fallen foul upon the goddess, and used her worse than a common strumpet, without the least provoâˆ£cation in nature.

I popp'd upon Smelfungus again at Turin, in his return home; and a sad tale of sorrowful adventures had he to tell,"wherein he spoke of moving accidents by flood and field, and of the cannibals which each other eat: the Anthropophagi"â€”he had been flea'd alive, and bedevil'd, and used worse than St. Bartholoâˆ£mew, at every stage he had come atâ€”
â€”I'll tell it, cried Smelfungus, to the world. You had better tell it, said I, to your physician.

Mundungus, with an immense forâˆ£tune, made the whole tour; going on from Rome to Naplesâ€”from Naples to Veniceâ€”from Venice to Viennaâ€”to Dresden, to Berlin, withâˆ£out one generous connection or pleasurâˆ£able anecdote to tell of; but he had travell'd straight on looking neither to his right hand or his left, lest Love or Pity should seduce him out of his road.

Peace be to them! if it is to be found; but heaven itself, was it posâˆ£sible to get there with such tempers,
would want objects to give itâ€”every gentle spirit would come flying upon the wings of Love to hail their arâˆ£rivalâ€”Nothing would the souls of Smelfungus and Mundungus hear of, but fresh anthems of joy, fresh rapâˆ£tures of love, and fresh congratulaâˆ£tions of their common felicityâ€”I heartily pity them: they have brought up no faculties for this work; and was the happiest mansion in heaven to be allotted to Smelfungus and Mundungus, they would be so far from being happy, that the souls of Smelfungus and Mundungus would do penance there to all eternity.

DIV1.HEAD: MONTRIUL.
DIV1.P: I HAD once lost my portmanteau from behind my chaise, and twice got out in the rain, and one of the times up to the knees in dirt, to help the postilion to tie it on, without beâˆ£ing able to find out what was wantâˆ£ingâ€”Nor was it till I got to Monâˆ£triul, upon the landlord's asking me if I wanted not a servant, that it ocâˆ£curred to me, that that was the very thing.

A servant! That I do most sadly, quoth Iâ€”Because, Monsieur, said the landlord, there is a clever young felâˆ£low,
who would be very proud of the honour to serve an Englishmanâ€”But why an English one, more than any other?â€”They are so generous, said the landlordâ€”I'll be shot if this is not a livre out of my pocket, quoth I to myself, this very nightâ€”But they have wherewithal to be so, Monsieur, added heâ€”Set down one livre more for that, quoth Iâ€”It was but last night, said the landlord, qu'un my Lord Anglois presentoit un ecu a la fille de chambreâ€”Tant pis, pour Madlle Janatone, said I.

Now Janatone being the landâˆ£lord's daughter, and the landlord supposing I was young in French, took the liberty to inform me, I should
not have said tant pisâ€”but, tant mieux. Tant mieux, toujours, Monsieur, said he, when there is any thing to be gotâ€”tant pis, when there is nothing. It comes to the same thing, said I. Pardonnez moi, said the landlord.

I cannot take a fitter opportunity to observe once for all, that tant pis and tant mieux being two of the great hinges in French conversation, a stranâˆ£ger would do well to set himself right in the use of them, before he gets to Paris.

A prompt French Marquis at our ambassador's table demanded of Mr. H, if he was H the poet?
No, said H mildlyâ€”Tant pis, replied the Marquis.
It is H the historian, said anâˆ£otherâ€”Tant mieux, said the Marquis. And Mr. H, who is a man of an excellent heart, return'd thanks for both.

When the landlord had set me right in this matter, he called in La Fleur, which was the name of the young man he had spoke ofâ€”saying only first, That as for his talents, he would presume to say nothingâ€”Monâˆ£sieur was the best judge what would suit him; but for the fidelity of La Fleur, he would stand responsible in all he was worth.

The landlord deliver'd this in a manner which instantly set my mind to the business I was uponâ€”and La Fleur, who stood waiting without, in that breathless expectation which every son of nature of us have felt in our turns, came in.

DIV1.HEAD: MONTRIUL.
DIV1.P: I AM apt to be taken with all kinds of people at first sight; but never more so, than when a poor devil comes to offer his service to so poor a devil as myself; and as I know this weakness, I always suffer my judgâˆ£ment to draw back something on that very accountâ€”and this more or less, according to the mood I am in, and the caseâ€”and I may add the gender too, of the person I am to govern.

When La Fleur enter'd the room, after every discount I could make for my soul, the genuine look and air of
the fellow determined the matter at once in his favour; so I hired him firstâ€”and then began to inquire what he could do: But I shall find out his talents, quoth I, as I want themâ€”besides, a Frenchman can do every thing.

Now poor La Fleur could do noâˆ£thing in the world but beat a drum, and play a march or two upon the fife. I was determined to make his talents do; and can't say my weakâˆ£ness was ever so insulted by my wisâˆ£dom, as in the attempt.

La Fleur had set out early in life, as gallantly as most Frenchmen do, with serving for a few years; at the end
of which, having satisfied the sentiâˆ£ment, and found moreover, That the honour of beating a drum was likely to be its own reward, as it open'd no further track of glory to himâ€”he retired a ses terres, and lived comme il plaisoit a Dieuâ€”that is to say, upon nothing.

â€”And so, quoth Wisdome, you have hired a drummer to attend you in this tour of your's thro' France and Italy! Psha! said I, and do not one half of our gentry go with a hum-drum compagnon du voiage the same round, and have the piper and the devil and all to pay besides? When man can extricate himself with
an equivoque in such an unequal matchâ€”he is not ill ofâ€”But you can do something else, La Fleur? said Iâ€”O qu'oui!â€”he could make spatâˆ£terdashes, and play a little upon the fiddleâ€”Bravo! said Wisdomeâ€”Why, I play a bass myself, said Iâ€”we shall do very well.â€”You can shave, and dress a wig a little, La Fleur?â€”He had all the dispositions in the worldâ€”It is enough for heaven! said I, inâˆ£terrupting himâ€”and ought to be enough for meâ€”So supper coming in, and having a frisky English spaâˆ£niel on one side of my chair, and a French valet, with as much hilarity in his countenance as ever nature painted in one, on the otherâ€”I was
satisfied to my heart's content with my empire; and if monarchs knew what they would be at, they might be as satisfied as I was.

DIV1.HEAD: MONTRIUL.
DIV1.P:
AS La Fleur went the whole tour of France and Italy with me, and will be often upon the stage, I must interest the reader a little furâˆ£ther in his behalf, by saying, that I had never less reason to repent of the impulses which generally do deterâˆ£mine me, than in regard to this felâˆ£lowâ€”he was a faithful, affectionate, simple soul as ever trudged after the heels of a philosopher; and notwithâˆ£standing his talents of drum-beating and spatterdash-making, which, tho' very good in themselves, happen'd to be of no great service to me, yet
was I hourly recompenced by the festivity of his temperâ€”it supplied all defectsâ€”I had a constant resource in his looks in all difficulties and disâˆ£tresses of my ownâ€”I was going to have added, of his too; but La Fleur was out of the reach of every thing; for whether 'twas hunger or thirst; or cold or nakedness, or watchings, or whatever stripes of ill luck La Fleur met with in our journeyings, there was no index in his physiognomy to point them out byâ€”he was eterâˆ£nally the same; so that if I am a piece of a philosopher, which Satan now and then puts it into my head I amâ€”it always mortifies the pride of the conceit, by reflecting how much I owe to the complexional philosophy
of this poor fellow, for shaming me into one of a better kind. With all this, La Fleur had a small cast of the coxcombâ€”but he seemed at first sight to be more a coxcomb of nature than of art; and before I had been three days in Paris with himâ€”he seemed to be no coxcomb at all.

DIV1.HEAD: MONTRIUL.
DIV1.P: THE next morning La Fleur entering upon his employâˆ£ment, I delivered to him the key of my portmanteau with an inventory of my half a dozen shirts and silk pair of breeches; and bid him fasten all upon the chaiseâ€”get the horses put toâ€”and desire the landlord to come in with his bill.

C'est un garÃ§on de bonne fortune, said the landlord, pointing through the window to half a dozen wenches who had got round about La Fleur, and were most kindly taking their leave of him, as the postilion was leading out the horses. La Fleur kissed all their hands round and
round again, and thrice he wiped his eyes, and thrice he promised he would bring them all pardons from Rome.

The young fellow, said the landâˆ£lord, is beloved by all the town, and there is scarce a corner in Montriul where the want of him will not be felt: he has but one misfortune in the world, continued he, "He is always in love."â€”I am heartily glad of it, said I,â€”'twill save me the trouble every night of putting my breeches under my head. In saying this, I was making not so much La Fleur's eloge, as my own, having been in love with one princess or another almost all my life, and I
hope I shall go on so, till I die, being firmly persuaded, that if ever I do a mean action, it must be in some interval betwixt one passion and another: whilst this interregnum lasts, I always perceive my heart locked upâ€”I can scarce find in it, to give Misery a sixpence; and thereâˆ£fore I always get out of it as fast as I can, and the moment I am reâˆ£kindled, I am all generosity and good will again; and would do any thing in the world either for, or with any one, if they will but satisfy me there is no sin in it.
â€”But in saying thisâ€”surely I am commending the passionâ€”not myâˆ£self.

DIV1.HEAD: A FRAGMENT.
DIV1.P: â€”THE town of Abdera, notwithstanding Democritus lived there trying all the powers of irony and laughter to reclaim it, was the vilest and most profligate town in all Thrace. What for poisons, conspiâˆ£racies and assassinationsâ€”libels, pasâˆ£quinades and tumults, there was no going there by dayâ€”'twas worse by night.

Now, when things were at the worst, it came to pass, that the Anâˆ£dromeda of Euripides being repreâˆ£sented at Abdera, the whole orchestra was delighted with it: but of all the
passages which delighted them, noâˆ£thing operated more upon their imaâˆ£ginations, than the tender strokes of nature which the poet had wrought up in that pathetic speech of Perseus,O Cupid, prince of God and men, &c. Every man almost spoke pure iamâˆ£bics the next day, and talk'd of noâˆ£thing but Perseus his pathetic adâˆ£dressâ€”"O Cupid! prince of God and men"â€”in every street of Abâˆ£dera, in every houseâ€”"O Cupid! Cupid!"â€”in every mouth, like the natural notes of some sweet melody which drops from it whether it will or noâ€”nothing but "Cupid! Cupid! prince of God and men"â€”The fire caughtâ€”and the whole city, like
the heart of one man, open'd itself to Love.

No pharmacopolist could sell one grain of heleboreâ€”not a single arâˆ£mourer had a heart to forge one inâˆ£strument of deathâ€”Friendship and Virtue met together, and kiss'd each other in the streetâ€”the golden age return'd, and hung o'er the town of Abderaâ€”every Abderite took his oaten pipe, and every Abderitish woman left her purple web, and chastly sat her down and listen'd to the songâ€”

'Twas only in the power, says the Fragment, of the God whose empire
extendeth from heaven to earth, and even to the depths of the sea, to have done this.

DIV1.HEAD: MONTRIUL.
DIV1.P:
WHEN all is ready, and every article is disputed and paid for in the inn, unless you are a little sour'd by the adventure, there is alâˆ£ways a matter to compound at the door, before you can get into your chaise; and that is with the sons and daughters of poverty, who surround you. Let no man say, "let them go to the devil"â€”'tis a cruel jourâˆ£ney to send a few miserables, and they have had sufferings enow withâˆ£out it: I always think it better to take a few sous out in my hand; and I would counsel every gentle travelâˆ£ler
to do so likewise: he need not be so exact in setting down his motives for giving themâ€”they will be reâˆ£gister'd elsewhere.
For my own part, there is no man gives so little as I do; for few that I know have so little to give: but as this was the first publick act of my charity in France, I took the more notice of it.
A well-a-way! said I. I have but eight sous in the world, shewing them in my hand, and there are eight poor men and eight poor women for 'em.

A poor tatter'd soul without a shirt on instantly withdrew his claim, by
retiring two steps out of the circle, and making a disqualifying bow on his part. Had the whole parterre cried out, Place aux dames, with one voice, it would not have conveyed the sentiment of a deference for the sex with half the effect.
Just heaven! for what wise reasons hast thou order'd it, that beggary and urbanity, which are at such variance in other countries, should find a way to be at unity in this?
â€”I insisted upon presenting him with a single sous, merely for his poâˆ£litesse.

A poor little dwarfish brisk fellow, who stood over-against me in the circle, putting something first under his arm, which had once been a hat, took his snuff-box out of his pocket, and generously offer'd a pinch on both sides of him: it was a gift of consequence, and modestly declinedâ€”The poor little fellow press'd it upon them with a nod of welcomenessâ€”Prenez enâ€”prenez, said he, lookâˆ£ing another way; so they each took a pinchâ€”Pity thy box should ever want one! said I to myself; so I put a couple of sous into itâ€”taking a small pinch out of his box, to enâˆ£hance their value, as I did itâ€”He felt the weight of the second obligaâˆ£tion more than that of the firstâ€”'twas
doing him an honourâ€”the other was only doing him a charityâ€”and he made me a bow down to the ground for it.
â€”Here! said I to an old soldier with one hand, who had been camâˆ£paign'd and worn out to death in the serviceâ€”here's a couple of sous for theeâ€”Vive le Roi! said the old solâˆ£dier.

I had then but three sous left: so I gave one, simply pour l'amour de Dieu, which was the footing on which it was begg'dâ€”The poor woman had a dislocated hip; so it could not be well, upon any other motive.
Mon cher et tres charitable Monâˆ£sieurâ€”There's no opposing this, said I.

My Lord Angloisâ€”the very sound was worth the moneyâ€”so I gave my last sous for it. But in the eagerness of giving, I had overlook'd a pauvre honteux, who had no one to ask a sous for him, and who, I believed, would have perish'd, ere he could have ask'd one for himself: he stood by the chaise a little without the circle, and wiped a tear from a face which I thought had seen better daysâ€”Good God! said Iâ€”and I have not one single sous left to give himâ€”But you have a thousand! cried all the powers of nature, stirring within meâ€”so I gave himâ€”no matter whatâ€”I am
ashamed to say how much, nowâ€”and was ashamed to think, how little, then: so if the reader can form any conjecture of my disposition, as these two fixed points are given him, he may judge within a livre or two what was the precise sum.

I could afford nothing for the rest, but, Dieu vous benisseâ€”Et le bon Dieu vous benisse encoreâ€”said the old solâˆ£dier, the dwarf, &c. The pauvre honteux could say nothingâ€”he pull'd out a little handkerchief, and wiped his face as he turned awayâ€”and I thought he thank'd me more than them all.

DIV1.HEAD: THE BIDET.
DIV1.P: HAVING settled all these little matters, I got into my postâˆ£chaise with more ease than ever I got into a post-chaise in my life; and La Fleur having got one large jackâˆ£boot on the far side of a little bidetPost horse., and another on this (for I count noâˆ£thing of his legs)â€”he canter'd away before me as happy and as perpenâˆ£dicular as a prince.â€”

â€”But what is happiness! what is grandeur in this painted scene of life! A dead ass, before we had got a league, put a sudden stop to La Fleur's careerâ€”his bidet would not
pass by itâ€”a contention arose betwixt them, and the poor fellow was kick'd out of his jack-boots the very first kick.

La Fleur bore his fall like a French christian, saying neither more or less upon it, than, Diable! so presently got up and came to the charge again astride his bidet, beatâˆ£ing him up to it as he would have beat his drum.

The bidet flew from one side of the road to the other, then back againâ€”then this wayâ€”then that way, and in short every way but by the dead ass.â€”La Fleur insisted upon the thingâ€”and the bidet threw him.

What's the matter, La Fleur, said I, with this bidet of thine?â€”Monâˆ£sieur, said he, c'est un cheval le plus opiniatrÃ© du mondeâ€”Nay, if he is a conceited beast, he must go his own way, replied Iâ€”so La Fleur got off him, and giving him a good sound lash, the bidet took me at my word, and away he scamper'd back to Montriul.â€”Peste! said La Fleur.

It is not mal a propos to take noâˆ£tice here, that tho' La Fleur availed himself but of two different terms of exclamation in this encounterâ€”namely, Diable! and Peste! that there are nevertheless three, in the French language; like the positive, comparative, and superlative, one or
the other of which serve for every unexpected throw of the dice in life.

Le Diable! which is the first, and positive degree, is generally used upon ordinary emotions of the mind, where small things only fall out contrary to your expectationsâ€”such asâ€”the throwing once doubletsâ€”La Fleur's being kick'd off his horse, and so forthâ€”cuckoldom, for the same reason, is alwaysâ€”Le Diable!
But in cases where the cast has something provoking in it, as in that of the bidet's running away after, and leaving La Fleur aground in jack-bootsâ€”'tis the second degree.
'Tis then Peste!
And for the thirdâ€”

â€”But here my heart is wrung with pity and fellow-feeling, when I reflect what miseries must have been their lot, and how bitterly so refined a people must have smarted, to have forced them upon the use of it.â€”
Grant me, O ye powers which touch the tongue with eloquence in distress!â€”whatever is my cast, Grant me but decent words to exclaim in, and I will give my nature way.

â€”But as these were not to be had in France, I resolved to take every
evil just as it befell me without any exclamation at all.

La Fleur, who had made no such covenant with himself, followed the bidet with his eyes till it was got out of sightâ€”and then, you may imagine, if you please, with what word he closed the whole affair.
As there was no hunting down a frighten'd horse in jack-boots, there remained no alternative but taking La Fleur either behind the chaise, or into it.â€”
I preferred the latter, and in half an hour we got to the post-house at Nampont.

DIV1.HEAD: NAMPONT.
THE DEAD ASS.
DIV1.P:
â€”AND this, said he, putting the remains of a crust into his walletâ€”and this, should have been thy portion, said he, hadst thou been alive to have shared it with me. I thought by the accent, it had been an apostrophe to his child; but 'twas to his ass, and to the very ass we had seen dead in the road, which had occasioned La Fleur's misadventure. The man seemed to lament it much; and it instantly brought into my mind Sancho's laâˆ£mentation
for his; but he did it with more true touches of nature.

The mourner was sitting upon a stone bench at the door, with the ass's pannel and its bridle on one side, which he took up from time to timeâ€”then laid them downâ€”look'd at them and shook his head. He then took his crust of bread out of his wallet again, as if to eat it; held it some time in his handâ€”then laid it upon the bit of his ass's bridleâ€”looked wistfully at the little arrangeâˆ£ment he had madeâ€”and then gave a sigh.

The simplicity of his grief drew numbers about him, and La Fleur
amongst the rest, whilst the horses were getting ready; as I continued sitting in the post-chaise, I could see and hear over their heads.

â€”He said he had come last from Spain, where he had been from the furthest borders of Franconia; and had got so far on his return home, when his ass died. Every one seem'd desirous to know what business could have taken so old and poor a man so far a journey from his own home.

It had pleased heaven, he said, to bless him with three sons, the finest lads in all Germany; but having in one week lost two of the eldest of them by the small-pox, and the
youngest falling ill of the same diâˆ£stemper, he was afraid of being bereft of them all; and made a vow, if Heaven would not take him from him also, he would go in gratitude to St. Iago in Spain.
When the mourner got thus far on his story, he stopp'd to pay nature her tributeâ€”and wept bitterly.

He said, Heaven had accepted the conditions; and that he had set out from his cottage with this poor creaâˆ£ture, who had been a patient partner of his journeyâ€”that it had eat the same bread with him all the way, and was unto him as a friend.

Every body who stood about, heard the poor fellow with concernâ€”â€”La Fleur offered him money.â€”The mourner said, he did not want itâ€”it was not the value of the assâ€”but the loss of him.â€”The ass, he said, he was assured loved himâ€”and upon this told them a long story of a mischance upon their passage over the Pyrenean mountains which had separated them from each other three days; during which time the ass had sought him as much as he had sought the ass, and that they had neither scarce eat or drank till they met.

Thou hast one comfort, friend, said I, at least in the loss of thy poor beast; I'm sure thou hast been a merâˆ£ciful
master to him.â€”Alas! said the mourner, I thought so, when he was aliveâ€”but now that he is dead I think otherwise.â€”I fear the weight of myself and my afflictions together have been too much for himâ€”they have shortened the poor creature's days, and I fear I have them to answer for.â€”Shame on the world! said I to myselfâ€”Did we love each other, as this poor soul but loved his assâ€”'twould be something.â€”

DIV1.HEAD: NAMPONT.
THE POSTILLION.
DIV1.P: THE concern which the poor fellow's story threw me into, required some attention: the poâˆ£stillion paid not the least to it, but set off upon the pavÃ¨ in a full gallop.

The thirstiest soul in the most sandy desert of Arabia could not have wished more for a cup of cold water, than mine did for grave and quiet movements; and I should have had an high opinion of the postillion had he but stolen off with me in someâˆ£thing like a pensive pace.â€”On the
contrary, as the mourner finished his lamentation, the fellow gave an unâˆ£feeling lash to each of his beasts, and set off clattering like a thousand devils.

I called to him as loud as I could, for heaven's sake to go slowerâ€”and the louder I called the more unmerâˆ£cifully he galloped.â€”The deuce take him and his galloping tooâ€”said Iâ€”he'll go on tearing my nerves to pieces till he has worked me into a foolish passion, and then he'll go slow, that I may enjoy the sweets of it.

The postillion managed the point to a miracle: by the time he had got
to the foot of a steep hill about half a league from Nampont,â€”he had put me out of temper with himâ€”and then with myself, for being so.
My case then required a different treatment; and a good rattling gallop would have been of real service to me.â€”
â€”Then, prithee get onâ€”get on, my good lad, said I.

The postillion pointed to the hillâ€”I then tried to return back to the story of the poor German and his assâ€”but I had broke the clueâ€”and could no more get into it again, than the postillion could into a trot.â€”
â€”The deuce go, said I, with it all! Here am I sitting as candidly disposed to make the best of the worst, as ever wight was, and all runs counter.
There is one sweet lenitive at least for evils, which nature holds out to us; so I took it kindly at her hands, and fell asleep; and the first word which roused me was Amiens.
â€”Bless me! said I, rubbing my eyesâ€”this is the very town where my poor lady is to come.

DIV1.HEAD: AMIENS.
DIV1.P:
THE words were scarce out of my mouth, when the Count de L***'s post-chaise, with his sister in it, drove hastily by: she had just time to make me a bow of reâˆ£cognitionâ€”and of that particular kind of it, which told me she had not yet done with me. She was as good as her look; for, before I had quite finished my supper, her broâˆ£ther's servant came into the room with a billet, in which she said, she had taken the liberty to charge me with a letter, which I was to present myself to Madame R*** the first
morning I had nothing to do at Paris. There was only added, she was sorry, but from what penchant she had not considered, that she had been preâˆ£vented telling me her storyâ€”that she still owed it me; and if my rout should ever lay through Brussels, and I had not by then forgot the name of Maâˆ£dame de L***â€”that Madame de L*** would be glad to discharge her obligation.

Then I will meet thee, said I, fair spirit! at Brusselsâ€”'tis only returnâˆ£ing from Italy through Germany to Holland, by the rout of Flanders, homeâ€”'twill scarce be ten posts out of my way; but were it ten thouâˆ£sand! with what a moral delight will
it crown my journey, in sharing in the sickening incidents of a tale of misery told to me by such a sufferer? to see her weep! and though I canâˆ£not dry up the fountain of her tears, what an exquisite sensation is there still left, in wiping them away from off the cheeks of the first and fairest of women, as I'm sitting with my handkerchief in my hand in silence the whole night besides her.
There was nothing wrong in the sentiment; and yet I instantly reâˆ£proached my heart with it in the bitâˆ£terest and most reprobate of expresâˆ£sions.

It had ever, as I told the reader, been one of the singular blessings of my life, to be almost every hour of it miserably in love with some one; and my last flame happening to be blown out by a whiff of jealousy on the sudden turn of a corner, I had lighted it up afresh at the pure taper of Eliza but about three months beâˆ£foreâ€”swearing as I did it, that it should last me through the whole journeyâ€”Why should I dissemble the matter? I had sworn to her eternal fidelityâ€”she had a right to my whole heartâ€”to divide my affections was to lessen themâ€”to expose them, was to risk them: where there is risk, there may be lossâ€”and what wilt
thou have, Yorick! to answer to a heart so full of trust and confidenceâ€”so good, so gentle and unreproachâˆ£ing?

â€”I will not go to Brussels, replied I, interrupting myselfâ€”but my imagiâˆ£nation went onâ€”I recall'd her looks at that crisis of our separation when neither of us had power to say Adieu! I look'd at the picture she had tied in a black ribband about my neckâ€”and blush'd as I look'd at itâ€”I would have given the world to have kiss'd it,â€”but was ashamedâ€”And shall this tender flower, said I, pressing it beâˆ£tween my handsâ€”shall it be smitten to its very rootâ€”and smitten, Yorick!
by thee, who hast promised to shelter it in thy breast?

Eternal fountain of happiness! said I, kneeling down upon the groundâ€”be thou my witnessâ€”and every pure spirit which tastes it, be my witness also, That I would not travel to Brussels, unless Eliza went along with me, did the road lead me toâˆ£wards heaven.
In transports of this kind, the heart, in spite of the understanding, will always say too much.

DIV1.HEAD: THE LETTER.
AMIENS.
DIV1.P:
FORTUNE had not smiled upon La Fleur; for he had been unsuccessful in his feats of chivalryâ€”and not one thing had offer'd to signalize his zeal for my service from the time he had enter'd into it, which was almost four and twenty hours. The poor soul burn'd with impaâˆ£tience; and the Count de L***'s servant's coming with the letter, beâˆ£ing the first practicable occasion which offered, La Fleur had laid hold of it; and in order to do honour to his
master, had taken him into a back parlour in the Auberge, and treated him with a cup or two of the best wine in Picardy; and the Count de L***'s servant in return, and not to be behind hand in politeness with La Fleur, had taken him back with him to the Count's hÃ´tel. La Fleur's prevenancy (for there was a passport in his very looks) soon set every serâˆ£vant in the kitchen at ease with him; and as a Frenchman, whatever be his talents, has no sort of prudery in shewing them, La Fleur, in less than five minutes, had pull'd out his fife, and leading off the dance himself with the first note, set the fille de chambre, the maitre d'hotel, the cook,
the scullion, and all the houshold, dogs and cats, besides an old monkey, a dancing: I suppose there never was a merrier kitchen since the flood.

Madame de L***, in passing from her brother's apartments to her own, hearing so much jollity below stairs, rung up her fille de chambre to ask about it; and hearing it was the English gentleman's servant who had set the whole house merry with his pipe, she order'd him up.

As the poor fellow could not preâˆ£sent himself empty, he had loaden'd himself in going up stairs with a thouâˆ£sand compliments to Madame de L***, on the part of his masterâ€”
added a long apocrypha of inquiries after Madame de L***'s healthâ€”told her, that Monsieur his master was au desespoire for her re-establishâˆ£ment from the fatigues of her jourâˆ£neyâ€”and, to close all, that Monâˆ£sieur had received the letter which Madame had done him the honourâ€”And he has done me the hoâˆ£nour, said Madame de L***, interâˆ£rupting La Fleur, to send a billet in return.

Madame de L*** had said this with such a tone of reliance upon the fact, that La Fleur had not power to disappoint her expectationsâ€”he trembled for my honourâ€”and posâˆ£sibly might not altogether be unconâˆ£cerned
for his own, as a man capable of being attach'd to a master who could be a wanting en egards vis a vis d'une femme; so that when Maâˆ£dame de L*** asked La Fleur if he had brought a letterâ€”O qu'oui, said La Fleur: so laying down his hat upon the ground, and taking hold of the flap of his right side pocket with his left hand, he began to search for the letter with his rightâ€”then contrary-wiseâ€”Diable!â€”then sought every pocketâ€”pocket by pocket, round, not forgetting his fobâ€”Peste!â€”then La Fleur emptied them upon the floorâ€”pulled out a dirty cravatâ€”a handkerchiefâ€”a combâ€”a whip lashâ€”a night-capâ€”then gave a peep
into his hatâ€”Quelle etourderie! He had left the letter upon the table in the Aubergeâ€”he would run for it, and be back with it in three minutes.

I had just finished my supper when La Fleur came in to give me an acâˆ£count of his adventure: he told the whole story simply as it was; and only added, that if Monsieur had forgot (par hazard) to answer Maâˆ£dame's letter, the arrangement gave him an opportunity to recover the faux pasâ€”and if not, that things were only as they were.

Now I was not altogether sure of my etiquette, whether I ought to have wrote or no; but if I hadâ€”a devil
himself could not have been angry 'twas but the officious zeal of a wellâˆ£meaning creature for my honour; and however he might have mistook the roadâ€”or embarrassed me in so doingâ€”his heart was in no faultâ€”I was under no necessity to writeâ€”and what weighed more than allâ€”he did not look as if he had done amiss.

â€”'Tis all very well, La Fleur, said I.â€”'Twas sufficient. La Fleur flew out of the room like lightening, and return'd with pen, ink, and paper, in his hand; and coming up to the table, laid them close before me, with such a delight in his counâˆ£tenance, that I could not help taking up the pen.
I begun and begun again; and though I had nothing to say, and that nothing might have been express'd in half a dozen lines, I made half a dozen different beginnings, and could no way please myself.
In short, I was in no mood to write.

La Fleur stepp'd out and brought a little water in a glass to dilute my inkâ€”then fetch'd sand and seal-waxâ€”It was all one: I wrote, and blotâˆ£ted, and tore off, and burnt, and wrote againâ€”Le Diable l'emporte! said I half to myselfâ€”I cannot write this self-same letter; throwing the pen down despairingly as I said it.

As soon as I had cast down the pen, La Fleur advanced with the most respectful carriage up to the table, and making a thousand apoloâˆ£gies for the liberty he was going to take, told me he had a letter in his pocket wrote by a drummer in his regiment to a corporal's wife, which, he durst say, would suit the occasion.
I had a mind to let the poor fellow have his humourâ€”Then prithee, said I, let me see it.

La Fleur instantly pull'd out a little dirty pocket-book cramm'd full of small letters and billet-doux in a sad condition, and laying it upon the table, and then untying the string
which held them all together, run them over one by one, till he came to the letter in questionâ€”La voila! said he, clapping his hands: so unâˆ£folding it first, he laid it before me, and retired three steps from the table whilst I read it.

DIV1.HEAD: THE LETTER.

LETTER.P: JE suis penetrÃ© de la douleur la plus vive, et reduit en mÃªme temps an desespoir par ce retour imprevÃ» du Corporal qui rend notre entrevue de ce soir la chose du monde la plus impossible.
Mais vive la joie! et toute la mienne sera de penser a vous.
Et le sentiment est encore moins sans amour.
On dit qu'on ne doit jamais se desesperer.
On dit aussi que Monsieur le Corâˆ£poral monte la garde Mecredi: alors ce sera mon tour.
En attendantâ€”Vive l'amour! et vive la bagatelle!

CLOSER.SIGNED:
Je suis, MADAME,
Avec toutes les sentiments les plus respecteux et les plus tendres tout a vous,
JAQUES ROQUE.

DIV1.P: It was but changing the Corporal into the Countâ€”and saying nothing about mounting guard on Wednesâˆ£dayâ€”and the letter was neither right or wrongâ€”so to gratify the poor felâˆ£low, who stood trembling for my honour, his own, and the honour of his letter,â€”I took the cream gently off it, and whipping it up in my own wayâ€”I seal'd it up and sent him with it to Madame de L***â€”and the next morning we pursued our jourâˆ£ney to Paris.

DIV1.HEAD: PARIS.
DIV1.P: WHEN a man can contest the point by dint of equipage, and carry all on floundering before him with half a dozen lackies and a couple of cooksâ€”'tis very well in such a place as Parisâ€”he may drive in at which end of a street he will.

A poor prince who is weak in cavalry, and whose whole infantry does not exceed a single man, had best quit the field; and signalize himself in the cabinet, if he can get up into itâ€”I say up into itâ€”for there is no descending perpendicular amongst 'em with a "Me voici!
mes enfans"â€”here I amâ€”whatever many may think.

I own my first sensations, as soon as I was left solitary and alone in my own chamber in the hotel, were far from being so flattering as I had preâˆ£figured them. I walked up gravely to the window in my dusty black coat, and looking through the glass saw all the world in yellow, blue, and green, running at the ring of pleasure.â€”The old with broken lances, and in helmets which had lost their vizardsâ€”the young in arâˆ£mour bright which shone like gold, beplumed with each gay feather of the eastâ€”allâ€”all tilting at it like
