fascinated knights in tournaments of yore for fame and love.â€”

Alas, poor Yorick! cried I, what art thou doing here? On the very first onset of all this glittering clatter, thou art reduced to an atomâ€”seekâ€”seek some winding alley, with a tourniquet at the end of it, where chariot never rolled or flambeau shot its raysâ€”there thou mayest solace thy soul in converse sweet with some kind grisset of a barber's wife, and get into such coteries!â€”

â€”May I perish! if I do, said I, pulling out the letter which I had to present to Madame de R***.â€”I'll
wait upon this lady, the very first thing I do. So I called La Fleur to go seek me a barber directlyâ€”and come back and brush my coat.

DIV1.HEAD: THE WIG.
PARIS.
DIV1.P: WHEN the barber came, he absolutely refused to have any thing to do with my wig: 'twas either above or below his art: I had nothing to do, but to take one ready made of his own recomâˆ£mendation.
â€”But I fear, friend! said I, this buckle won't stand.â€”You may imâˆ£merge it, replied he, into the ocean, and it will standâ€”

What a great scale is every thing upon in this city! thought Iâ€”The
utmost stretch of an English periwigâˆ£maker's ideas could have gone no further than to have "dipped it into a pail of water"â€”What difference! 'tis like time to eternity.

I confess I do hate all cold conâˆ£ceptions, as I do the puny ideas which engender them; and am geâˆ£nerally so struck with the great works of nature, that for my own part, if I could help it, I never would make a comparison less than a mountain at least. All that can be said against the French sublime in this instance of it, is thisâ€”that the grandeur is more in the word; and less in the thing. No doubt the ocean fills the mind with vast ideas;
but Paris being so far inland, it was not likely I should run post a hundred miles out of it, to try the experimentâ€”the Parisian barber meant nothing.â€”

The pail of water standing besides the great deep, makes certainly but a sorry figure in speechâ€”but 'twill be saidâ€”it has one advantageâ€”'tis in the next room, and the truth of the buckle may be tried in it without more ado, in a single moment.
In honest truth, and upon a more candid revision of the matter, The French expression professes more than it performs.

I think I can see the precise and distinguishing marks of national chaâˆ£racters more in these nonsensical miâˆ£nutiae, than in the most important matters of state; where great men of all nations talk and stalk so much alike, that I would not give nineâˆ£pence to chuse amongst them.

I was so long in getting from under my barber's hands, that it was too late of thinking of going with my letter to Madame R*** that night: but when a man is once dressed at all points for going out, his reflections turn to little account, so taking down the name of the Hotel de Modene where I lodged, I
walked forth without any determiâˆ£nation where to goâ€”I shall consider of that, said I, as I walk along.

DIV1.HEAD: THE PULSE.
PARIS.
DIV1.P: HAIL ye small sweet courtesies of life, for smooth do ye make the road of it! like grace and beauty which beget inclinations to love at first sight; 'tis ye who open this door and let the stranger in.
â€”Pray, Madame, said I, have the goodness to tell me which way I must turn to go to the Opera comique:â€”Most willingly, Monsieur, said she, laying aside her workâ€”

I had given a cast with my eye into half a dozen shops as I came
along in search of a face not likely to be disordered by such an interrupâˆ£tion; till at last, this hitting my fancy, I had walked in.
She was working a pair of ruffles as she sat in a low chair on the far side of the shop facing the doorâ€”

â€”Tres volentieres; most willingly, said she, laying her work down upon a chair next her, and rising up from the low chair she was sitting in, with so chearful a movement and so chearful a look, that had I been laying out fifty louis d'ors with her, I should have saidâ€”"This woman is grateful."

You must turn, Monsieur, said she, going with me to the door of the shop, and pointing the way down the street I was to takeâ€”you must turn first to your left handâ€”mais prenez guardeâ€”there are two turns; and be so good as to take the secondâ€”then go down a little way and you'll see a church, and when you are past it, give yourself the trouble to turn directly to the right, and that will lead you to the foot of the pont neuf, which you must crossâ€”and there, any one will do himself the pleasure to shew youâ€”

She repeated her instructions three times over to me with the same good natur'd patience the third time
as the first;â€”and if tones and manners have a meaning, which certainly they have, unless to hearts which shut them outâ€”she seem'd really interested, that I should not lose myself.

I will not suppose it was the woâˆ£man's beauty, notwithstanding she was the handsomest grisset, I think, I ever saw, which had much to do with the sense I had of her courtesy; only I remember, when I told her how much I was obliged to her, that I looked very full in her eyes,â€”and that I repeated my thanks as often as she had done her instructions.

I had not got ten paces from the door, before I found I had forgot
every tittle of what she had saidâ€”so looking back, and seeing her still standing in the door of the shop as if to look whether I went right or notâ€”I returned back, to ask her whether the first turn was to my right or leftâ€”for that I had absolutely forgot.â€”Is it possible! said she, half laughing.â€”'Tis very possible, replied I, when a man is thinking more of a woman, than of her good advice.
As this was the real truthâ€”she took it, as every woman takes a matter of right, with a slight courtesy.

â€”Attendez! said she, laying her hand upon my arm to detain me, whilst she called a lad out of the
back-shop to get ready a parcel of gloves. I am just going to send him, said she, with a packet into that quarter, and if you will have the complaisance to step in, it will be ready in a moment, and he shall attend you to the place.â€”So I walk'd in with her to the far side of the shop, and taking up the ruffle in my hand which she laid upon the chair, as if I had a mind to sit, she sat down herself in her low chair, and I instantly sat myself down besides her.

â€”He will be ready, Monsieur, said she, in a momentâ€”And in that moâˆ£ment, replied I, most willingly would I say something very civil to you for
all these courtesies. Any one may do a casual act of good nature, but a continuation of them shews it is a part of the temperature; and certainly, added I, if it is the same blood which comes from the heart, which deâˆ£scends to the extremes (touching her wrist) I am sure you must have one of the best pulses of any woman in the worldâ€”Feel it, said she, holding out her arm. So laying down my hat, I took hold of her fingers in one hand, and applied the two fore-fingers of my other to the arteryâ€”

â€”Would to heaven! my dear Euâˆ£genius, thou hadst passed by, and beheld me sitting in my black coat, and in my lack-a-day-sical manner,
counting the throbs of it, one by one, with as much true devotion as if I had been watching the critical ebb or flow of her feverâ€”How wouldst thou have laugh'd and moâˆ£ralized upon my new profession?â€”and thou shouldst have laugh'd and moralized onâ€”Trust me, my dear Eugenius, I should have said, "there are worse occupations in this world than feeling a woman's pulse."â€”But a Grisset's! thou wouldst have saidâ€”and in an open shop! Yorickâ€”
â€”So much the better: for when my views are direct, Eugenius, I care not if all the world saw me feel it.

DIV1.HEAD: THE HUSBAND.
PARIS.
DIV1.P:
I HAD counted twenty pulsations, and was going on fast towards the fortieth, when her husband comâˆ£ing unexpected from a back parlour into the shop, put me a little out in my reckoningâ€”'Twas no body but her husband, she saidâ€”so I began a fresh scoreâ€”Monsieur is so good, quoth she, as he pass'd by us, as to give himself the trouble of feeling my pulseâ€”The husband took off his hat, and making me a bow, said, I did him too much honourâ€”and havâˆ£ing
said that, he put on his hat and walk'd out.
Good God! said I to myself, as he went outâ€”and can this man be the husband of this woman?
Let it not torment the few who know what must have been the grounds of this exclamation, if I exâˆ£plain it to those who do not.

In London a shopkeeper and a shopkeeper's wife seem to be one bone and one flesh: in the several endowments of mind and body, someâˆ£times the one, sometimes the other has it, so as in general to be upon a par, and to tally with each other as nearly as man and wife need to do.

In Paris, there are scarce two orâˆ£ders of beings more different: for the legislative and executive powers of the shop not resting in the husâˆ£band, he seldom comes thereâ€”in some dark and dismal room behind, he sits commerceless in his thrum night-cap, the same rough son of Nature that Nature left him.

The genius of a people where noâˆ£thing but the monarchy is salique, having ceded this department, with sundry others, totally to the womenâ€”by a continual higgling with cusâˆ£tomers of all ranks and sizes from morning to night, like so many rough pebbles shook long together in a
bag, by amicable collisions, they have worn down their asperities and sharp angles, and not only become round and smooth, but will receive, some of them, a polish like a brilâˆ£liantâ€”Monsieur le Mari is little betâˆ£ter than the stone under your footâ€”
â€”Surelyâ€”surely man! it is not good for thee to sit aloneâ€”thou wast made for social intercourse and gentle greetings, and this improvement of our natures from it, I appeal to, as my evidence.

â€”And how does it beat, Monâˆ£sieur? said she.â€”With all the beâˆ£nignity, said I, looking quietly in
her eyes, that I expectedâ€”She was going to say something civil in reâˆ£turnâ€”but the lad came into the shop with the glovesâ€”A propos, said I; I want a couple of pair myself.

DIV1.HEAD: THE GLOVES.
PARIS.
DIV1.P:
THE beautiful Grisset rose up when I said this, and going behind the counter, reach'd down a parcel and untied it: I advanced to the side over-against her: they were all too large. The beautiful Grisset measured them one by one across my handâ€”It would not alter the dimenâˆ£sionsâ€”She begg'd I would try a single pair, which seemed to be the leastâ€”She held it openâ€”my hand slipp'd into it at onceâ€”It will not do, said I,
shaking my head a littleâ€”No, said she, doing the same thing.

There are certain combined looks of simple subtletyâ€”where whim, and sense, and seriousness, and nonsense, are so blended, that all the languages of Babel set loose together could not express themâ€”they are communiâˆ£cated and caught so instantaneously, that you can scarce say which party is the infecter. I leave it to your men of words to swell pages about itâ€”it is enough in the present to say again, the gloves would not do; so folding our hands within our arms, we both loll'd upon the counterâ€”it was narrow, and there was just room for the parcel to lay between us.

The beautiful Grisset look'd someâˆ£times at the gloves, then side-ways to the window, then at the glovesâ€”and then at me. I was not disposed to break silenceâ€”I follow'd her exâˆ£ample: so I look'd at the gloves, then to the window, then at the gloves, and then at herâ€”and so on alternately.

I found I lost considerably in every attackâ€”she had a quick black eye, and shot through two such long and silken eye-lashes with such penetraâˆ£tion, that she look'd into my very heart and reinsâ€”It may seem strange, but I could actually feel she didâ€”
â€”It is no matter, said I, taking up a couple of the pairs next me, and putting them into my pocket.

I was sensible the beautiful Grisset had not ask'd above a single livre above the priceâ€”I wish'd she had ask'd a livre more, and was puzzling my brains how to bring the matter aboutâ€”Do you think, my dear Sir, said she, mistaking my embarrassâˆ£ment, that I could ask a sous too much of a strangerâ€”and of a stranger whose politeness, more than his want of gloves, has done me the honour to lay himself at my mercy?â€”Men croyez capable?â€”Faith! not I, said I; and if you were, you are welcomeâ€”
So counting the money into her hand, and with a lower bow than one geneâˆ£rally makes to a shopkeeper's wife, I went out, and her lad with his parcel followed me.

DIV1.HEAD: THE TRANSLATION.
PARIS.
DIV1.P:
THERE was no body in the box I was let into but a kindly old French officer. I love the chaâˆ£racter, not only because I honour the man whose manners are softened by a profession which makes bad men worse; but that I once knew oneâ€”for he is no moreâ€”and why should I not rescue one page from violation by writing his name in it, and telling the world it was Captain Tobias Shandy, the dearest of my flock and friends, whose philanthropy I never
think of at this long distance from his deathâ€”but my eyes gush out with tears. For his sake, I have a predilection for the whole corps of veterans; and so I strode over the two back rows of benches, and placed myself beside him.

The old officer was reading attenâˆ£tively a small pamphlet, it might be the book of the opera, with a large pair of spectacles. As soon as I sat down, he took his spectacles off, and putting them into a shagreen case, return'd them and the book into his pocket together. I half rose up, and made him a bow.
Translate this into any civilized language in the worldâ€”the sense is this:

P.Q: "Here's a poor stranger come in to the boxâ€”he seems as if he knew no body; and is never likely, was he to be seven years in Paris, if every man he comes near keeps his spectacles upon his noseâ€”'tis shutting the door of conversation absolutely in his faceâ€”and using him worse than a German."

DIV1.P:
The French officer might as well have said it all aloud; and if he had, I should in course have put the bow I made him into French too, and told him, "I was sensible of his atâˆ£tention,
and return'd him a thouâˆ£sand thanks for it."

There is not a secret so aiding to the progress of sociality, as to get master of this short hand, and be quick in rendering the several turns of looks and limbs, with all their inflections and delineations, into plain words. For my own part, by long habitude, I do it so mechanically, that when I walk the streets of Lonâˆ£don, I go translating all the way; and have more than once stood beâˆ£hind in the circle, where not three words have been said, and have brought off twenty different dialogues with me, which I could have fairly wrote down and sworn to.

I was going one evening to Marâˆ£tini's concert at Milan, and was just entering the door of the hall, when the Marquesina di F*** was coming out in a sort of a hurryâ€”she was alâˆ£most upon me before I saw her; so I gave a spring to one side to let her passâ€”She had done the same, and on the same side too; so we ran our heads together: she instantly got to the other side to get out: I was just as unfortunate as she had been; for I had sprung to that side, and opâˆ£posed her passage againâ€”We both flew together to the other side, and then backâ€”and so onâ€”it was ridiâˆ£culous; we both blush'd intolerably; so I did at last the thing I should have
done at firstâ€”I stood stock still, and the Marquesina had no more diffiâˆ£culty. I had no power to go into the room, till I had made her so much reparation as to wait and folâˆ£low her with my eye to the end of the passageâ€”She look'd back twice, and walk'd along it rather side-ways, as if she would make room for any one coming up stairs to pass herâ€”No, said Iâ€”that's a vile translation: the Marquesina has a right to the best apology I can make her; and that opening is left for me to do it inâ€”so I ran and begg'd pardon for the embarrassment I had given her, saying it was my intention to have made her way. She answered, she
was guided by the same intention toâˆ£wards meâ€”so we reciprocally thank'd each other. She was at the top of the stairs; and seeing no chichesbee near her, I begg'd to hand her to her coachâ€”so we went down the stairs, stopping at every third step to talk of the concert and the adventureâ€”Upon my word, Madame, said I when I had handed her in, I made six different efforts to let you go outâ€”And I made six efforts, replied she, to let you enterâ€”I wish to heaven you would make a seventh, said Iâ€”With all my heart, said she, making roomâ€”Life is too short to be long about the forms of itâ€”so I instantly stepp'd in, and she carried me home with herâ€”And
what became of the concert, St. Ceâˆ£cilia, who, I suppose, was at it, knows more than I.
I will only add, that the connecâˆ£tion which arose out of that translaâˆ£tion, gave me more pleasure than any one I had the honour to make in Italy.

DIV1.HEAD: THE DWARF.
PARIS.
DIV1.P:
I HAD never heard the remark made by any one in my life, exâˆ£cept by one; and who that was, will probably come out in this chapter; so that being pretty much unpreposâˆ£sessed, there must have been grounds for what struck me the moment I cast my eyes over the parterreâ€”and that was, the unaccountable sport of nature in forming such numbers of dwarfsâ€”No doubt, she sports at cerâˆ£tain times in almost every corner of the world; but in Paris, there is no
end to her amusementsâ€”The godâˆ£dess seems almost as merry as she is wise.

As I carried my idea out of the opera comique with me, I measured every body I saw walking in the streets by itâ€”Melancholy application! espeâˆ£cially where the size was extremely littleâ€”the face extremely darkâ€”the eyes quickâ€”the nose longâ€”the teeth whiteâ€”the jaw prominentâ€”to see so many miserables, by force of acciâˆ£dents driven out of their own proper class into the very verge of another, which it gives me pain to write downâ€”every third man a pigmy!â€”some by ricketty heads and hump backsâ€”
others by bandy legsâ€”a third set arâˆ£rested by the hand of Nature in the sixth and seventh years of their growthâ€”a fourth, in their perfect and natural state, like dwarf appleâˆ£trees; from the first rudiments and stamina of their existence, never meant to grow higher.

A medical traveller might say, 'tis owing to undue bandagesâ€”a spleneâˆ£tic one, to want of airâ€”and an inâˆ£quisitive traveller, to fortify the sysâˆ£tem, may measure the height of their housesâ€”the narrowness of their streets, and in how few feet square in the sixth and seventh stories such numâˆ£bers of the Bourgoisie eat and sleep
together; but I remember, Mr. Shandy the elder, who accounted for nothing like any body else, in speakâˆ£ing one evening of these matters, averred, that children, like other aniâˆ£mals, might be increased almost to any size, provided they came right into the world; but the misery was, the citizens of Paris were so coop'd up, that they had not actually room enough to get themâ€”I do not call it getting any thing, said heâ€”'tis getâˆ£ting nothingâ€”Nay, continued he, rising in his argument, 'tis getting worse than nothing, when all you have got, after twenty or five and twenty years of the tenderest care and most nutritious aliment bestowed upâˆ£on
it, shall not at last be as high as my leg. Now, Mr. Shandy being very short, there could be nothing more said upon it.

As this is not a work of reasoning, I leave the solution as I found it, and content myself with the truth only of the remark, which is verified in every lane and by-lane of Paris. I was walking down that which leads from the Carousal to the Palais Royal, and observing a little boy in some distress at the side of the gutter, which ran down the middle of it, I took hold of his hand, and help'd him over. Upon turning up his face to look at him after, I perceived he was about
fortyâ€”Never mind, said I; some good body will do as much for me when I am ninety.

I feel some little principles within me, which incline me to be merciful towards this poor blighted part of my species, who have neither size or strength to get on in the worldâ€”I cannot bear to see one of them trod upon; and had scarce got seated beâˆ£side my old French officer, ere the disgust was exercised, by seeing the very thing happen under the box we sat in.

At the end of the orchestra, and betwixt that and the first side-box,
there is a small esplanade left, where, when the house is full, numbers of all ranks take sanctuary. Though you stand, as in the parterre, you pay the same price as in the orchestra. A poor defenceless being of this order had got thrust some how or other inâˆ£to this luckless placeâ€”the night was hot, and he was surrounded by beâˆ£ings two feet and a half higher than himself. The dwarf suffered inexâˆ£pressibly on all sides; but the thing which incommoded him most, was a tall corpulent German, near seven feet high, who stood directly betwixt him and all possibility of his seeing either the stage or the actors. The poor dwarf did all he could to get a
peep at what was going forwards, by seeking for some little opening beâˆ£twixt the German's arm and his body, trying first one side, then the other; but the German stood square in the most unaccommodating posture that can be imaginedâ€”the dwarf might as well have been placed at the bottom of the deepest draw-well in Paris; so he civilly reach'd up his hand to the German's sleeve, and told him his distressâ€”The German turn'd his head back, look'd down-upon him as Goâˆ£liah did upon Davidâ€”and unfeelâˆ£ingly resumed his posture.

I was just then taking a pinch of snuff out of my monk's little horn boxâ€”And how would thy meek and
courteous spirit, my dear monk! so temper'd to bear and forbear!â€”how sweetly would it have lent an ear to this poor soul's complaint!

The old French officer seeing me lift up my eyes with an emotion, as I made the apostrophe, took the liâˆ£berty to ask me what was the matterâ€”I told him the story in three words; and added, how inhuman it was.

By this time the dwarf was driven to extremes, and in his first transâˆ£ports, which are generally unreasonâˆ£able, had told the German he would cut off his long queue with his knifeâ€”The German look'd back coolly,
and told him he was welcome if he could reach it.

An injury sharpened by an insult, be it to who it will, makes every man of sentiment a party: I could have leaped out of the box to have redressed it.â€”The old French officer did it with much less confusion; for leaning a little over, and nodding to a centinel, and pointing at the same time with his finger to the distressâ€”the centinel made his way up to it.â€”There was no occasion to tell the grievanceâ€”the thing told itself; so thrusting back the German instantly with his musketâ€”he took the poor dwarf by the hand, and placed him
before him.â€”This is noble! said I, clapping my hands togetherâ€”And yet you would not permit this, said the old officer, in England.
â€”In England, dear Sir, said I, we sit all at our ease.

The old French officer would have set me at unity with myself, in case I had been at variance,â€”by saying it was a bon motâ€”and as a bon mot is always worth something at Paris, he offered me a pinch of snuff.

DIV1.HEAD: THE ROSE.
PARIS.
DIV1.P: IT was now my turn to ask the old French officer "What was the matter?" for a cry of "Haussez les mains, Monsieur l'Abbe," reâˆ£echoed from a dozen different parts of the parterre, was as unintellgible to me, as my apostrophe to the monk had been to him.

He told me, it was some poor Abbe in one of the upper loges, who he supposed had got planted perdu behind a couple of grissets in
order to see the opera, and that the parterre espying him, were insisting upon his holding up both his hands during the representation.â€”And can it be supposed, said I, that an ecâˆ£clesiastick would pick the Griffer's pockets? The old French officer smiled, and whispering in my car, open'd a door of knowledge which I had no idea ofâ€”

Good God! said I, turning pale with astonishmentâ€”is it possible, that a people so smit with sentiment should at the same time be so unclean, and so unlike themselvesâ€”Quelle grosâˆ£sierte! added I.

The French officer told me, it was an illiberal sarcasm at the church, which had begun in the theatre about the time the Tartuffe was given in it, by Moliereâ€”but, like other remains os Gothic manners, was decliningâ€”Every nation, continued he, have their refinements and grossiertes, in which they take the lead, and lose it of one another by turnsâ€”that he had been in most countries, but never in one where he found not some deliâˆ£cacies, which others seemed to want. Le POUR, et le CONTRE se trouvent en chaque nation; there is a balance, said he, of good and bad every where; and nothing but the knowing it is so can emancipate one half of the world
from the prepossessions which it holds against the otherâ€”that the advanâˆ£tage of travel, as it regarded the sÃ§aâˆ£voir vivre, was by seeing a great deal both of men and manners; it taught us mutual toleration; and mutual toleration, concluded he, making me a bow, taught us mutual love.

The old French officer delivered this with an air of such candour and good sense, as coincided with my first favourable impressions of his characâˆ£terâ€”I thought I loved the man; but I fear I mistook the objectâ€”'twas my own way of thinkingâ€”the difâˆ£ference was, I could not have exâˆ£pressed it half so well.

It is alike troublesome to both the rider and his beastâ€”if the latter goes pricking up his ears, and starting all the way at every object which he never saw beforeâ€”I have as little torment of this kind as any creature alive; and yet I honestly confess, that many a thing gave me pain, and that I blush'd at many a word the first monthâ€”which I found inconsequent and perfectly innocent the second.

Madame de Ramboulict, after an acquaintance of about six weeks with her, had done me the honour to take me in her coach about two leagues out of townâ€”Of all women, Maâˆ£dame de Rambouliet is the most corâˆ£rect; and I never wish to see one of
more virtues and purity of heartâ€”In our return back, Madame de Ramâˆ£bouliet desired me to pull the cordâ€”I ask'd her if she wanted any thingâ€”Rien que pisser, said Madame de Ramboulietâ€”

Grieve not, gentle traveller, to let Madame de Rambouliet pâ€”ss onâ€”And, ye fair mystic nymphs! go each one pluck your rose, and scatter them in your pathâ€”for Madame de Ramâˆ£bouliet did no moreâ€”I handed Maâˆ£dame de Rambouliet out of the coach; and had I been the priest of the chaste CASTALIA, I could not have served at her fountain with a more respectful decorum.
